metadata./Title: Chronic appendicitis misdiagnosed as a periappendiceal orifice polyp: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Unlike acute appendicitis, chronic appendicitis is characterized by nonspecific abdominal pain 
and intermittent course. This may lead to late diagnosis or misdiagnosis, with the possibility of serious complications.
Case report A male patient of Arab origin aged 55 years had a 2-year history of recurrent episodes of mild pain 
in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. The episodes were associated with nausea, chills, and abdominal bloat ing but no vomiting, rectal bleeding, or weight loss. On examination, the patient showed soft and lax abdomen 
with mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant, with no organomegaly or abdominal masses. Laboratory findings 
showed normal complete blood count and C-reactive protein. The patient underwent colonoscopy to rule out malignancy, which showed appendiceal orifice polyp that required resection. The computed tomography scan showed 
an enlarged appendix with multiple intraluminal dense appendicoliths. The largest stone at the appendiceal orifice 
measured 1.5 cm × 0.9 cm and was partially protruding within the cecal lumen. The diagnosis of chronic appendicitis 
was confirmed. The patient underwent appendectomy and was asymptomatic a few days after discharge.
Conclusions We are reporting a patient with chronic appendicitis presented with multiple appendicoliths. The 
patient was initially misdiagnosed as periappendiceal orifice polyp. The current finding highlights the importance 
of imaging, especially computed tomography in confirming the diagnosis in patients with atypical appendicitis 
presentation.
Keywords  Chronic appendicitis, Appendicoliths, Periappendiceal orifice polyp, Case report, Saudi Arabia
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is usually straight forward, with a 2-day history of abdominal pain that is 
localized later into the right lower quadrant of the abdo men that becomes tender and rigid [1]. Laboratory find ings including leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory 
markers usually confirm the diagnosis [2]. On the con trary, chronic appendicitis is characterized by nonspe cific abdominal pain that can be easily missed [3, 4]. The 
patient frequently presented with an easily managed mild recurrent abdominal pain that is not associated with leu kocytosis or other classic signs of acute appendicitis [4, 
5].
Chronic appendicitis is frequently misdiagnosed as 
urinary tract infection, tropical inflammatory diseases, 
colitis, pelvic inflammatory diseases, or even gastrointes tinal malignancy [4, 6]. The misdiagnosis and late diag nosis can cause serious complications, such as abscess 
formation, perforation, peritonitis, and infertility [3]. 
Although 7  days have been suggested to clinically dif ferentiate between acute and chronic presentation of 
appendicitis, the course of chronic appendicitis may take 
several months or even years [7, 8]. The use of diagnos tic imaging, especially computed tomography (CT) scan, 
has been very decisive in atypical presentation of acute 
appendicitis and in chronic appendicitis [8–10]. We are Open Access

Case report
A 55-year-old male patient of Arab origin was presented 
to the gastroenterology clinic with chronic abdominal 
pain. The patient reported a 2-year history of recurrent 
episodes of sharp stabbing pain in the right lower quad rant of the abdomen. The episodes occurred on average 
once or twice a week and usually lasted for 30–45  min. 
The pain was described as mild to moderate (2–3 out of 
10 points pain scale) and was relieved spontaneously or 
with pain killer. There were no reported aggravating or 
reliving factors. The episodes were associated with nau sea, chills, and abdominal bloating. The patient denied 
any associated vomiting, rectal bleeding, or weight loss. 
The patient reported once a day bowel movement (Bris tol stool type II). This was described as mild constipation. 
The patient had hypertension that is treated with amlodi pine and hyperlipidemia that is treated with atorvastatin.
On examination, the patient was conscious and ori ented. Vital signs showed normal blood pressure, heart 
beats, and respiratory rates. The patient was afebrile 
at the time of examination. The chest was clear with no 
signs of infection or wheezing. The heart examination 
was unremarkable with no signs of heart failure. Abdom inal examination showed soft and lax abdomen with mild 
tenderness in the right lower quadrant. There were no 
organomegaly or abdominal masses.
Laboratory findings showed normal complete blood 
count, C-reactive protein, sedimentation rate, electro lytes, blood glucose, liver function, and renal function. 
The patient underwent colonoscopy for colon cancer 
screening. The colonoscopy showed rounded protrud ing mass arising from appendiceal orifice with completely 
normal overlying mucosa and otherwise normal colon 
(Fig.  1). The patient was diagnosed as periappendiceal 
orifice polyp that is probably nonmalignant.
The patient was then referred to undergo full thickness 
resection of periappendiceal orifice polyp. After review ing the colonoscopy findings, the surgical team requested 
a CT scan imaging of the abdomen with intravenous 
contrast before resection. The CT showed an enlarged 
appendix with multiple intraluminal dense appendico liths (Fig.  2). The largest stone at the appendiceal orifice 
measured 1.5 cm × 0.9  cm and was partially protruding 
within the cecal lumen. The appendiceal wall was mildly 
thickened, with no surrounding fat stranding or collec tion. The ileocecal junction, rest of small bowel and colon 
appeared normal. The new findings were consistent with 
chronic appendicitis. The patient underwent appendec tomy and was asymptomatic a few days after discharge.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
We are reporting a patient with chronic appendicitis that 
was initially misdiagnosed as periappendiceal orifice 
polyp. Chronic appendicitis is a rare form of appendicitis, 
representing no more than 1.5% of all patients [4, 8]. As 
appendicitis is primarily a clinical diagnosis, atypical and 
mild course may lead to delayed or misdiagnosis [8]. The 
current patient had a 2-year history of recurrent abdomi nal pain. Previous data showed that the duration of nonspecific abdominal pain may be as short as days [9] or as 
long as months [3, 6] or years [4, 11]. The late diagno sis was probably helped by the lack of classic signs and 
symptoms of acute appendicitis, including severe pain 
and rigid abdomen that otherwise will force the patient 
to seek emergency care [3, 4].
The current patient had been misdiagnosed with peri appendiceal orifice polyp. This is a frequent nonmalig nant lesion that can be resected endoscopically [12].
However, they represent a challenge due to incom plete assessment of malignant possibility and incom plete endoscopic resection [12]. In the current patient, 
CT verification before resection was critical for reaching 
the correct diagnosis. CT is very confirmative in atypical 
presentation of appendicitis [8–10]. The sensitivity of CT 
reaching the correct diagnosis in patients with appendici tis is very high (93% and 99%) [8]. Additionally, it is much 
better than other radiologic modalities, such as X-ray and 
ultrasound [8, 9].

The current patient had multiple appendicoliths, which 
is seen in 10% of patients with appendicitis [13]. It is con sidered as calcified masses consisting of fecal particulates 
and inorganic salts [14]. Their diagnosis is easy using CT, 
X-ray, or even ultrasound. They probably caused a par tial obstruction of the appendiceal orifice of the current 
patient, resulting in chronic appendicitis symptoms. It 
was initially missed as colonoscopy is not the best modal ity to diagnose appendicitis. Colonoscopy was used 
to rule out malignancy in a patient with long history 
of abdominal pain. The patient was quickly treated by 
appendectomy as appendicoliths are known risk factors 
for appendix perforation and abscess formation [13, 14].
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion
We reported a patient with chronic appendicitis who 
presented with multiple appendicoliths. The patient was 
initially misdiagnosed with periappendiceal orifice polyp. 
The current finding highlights the importance of imag ing, especially CT in confirming the diagnosis in patients 
with atypical appendicitis presentation.
